prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The required sensitivity is set by the aim of detecting 13CH3CN in the disks surrounding our targets. The estimated line intensity, based on previous PdBI and SMA observations of three of our targets (Beltran et al. 2011, A&A, 525, A151; Beltran et al. 2011, A&A, 532, A91; Cesaroni et al. 2011, A&A, 533, A73) and the simulations presented in the scientific justification, is 20 mJy/beam. We need to detect this at the 10sigma level to perform the kinematic analysis. This implies a required rms of 2 mJy/beam in the 0.8 km/s channels. This velocity resolution will be sufficent to resolve and properly map the Keplerian velocity pattern (linewidth ~7 km/s). Continuum sensitivity is not an issue for our sources, as the minimum expected continuum flux density is 7 mJy and the continuum noise will be 0.15 mJy/beam, even with the conservative assumption that the line-free bandwidth is only 100 MHz. We require a dynamic range of ~100 in the continuum and ~150 for the brightest lines. We expect that self-calibration may be possible on the continuum source. The goal of this proposal is to resolve the hot and dense molecular emission around the central protostar. As explained in the next section, the tracers needed for our scientific goals are expected to show emission over regions <2". Thus the integration time is set by sensitivity considerations and not by (u,v) coverage requirements.
Time constraints: None
User defined calibrations: None

The spectra from these hot cores are expected to be extremely rich and the lines are typically broad (several km/s). We thus divided the correlator in several units with spectral resolutions ranging from 0.7 to 1.3 km/s. In particular, we will use different units to cover the following lines (one per unit): CH3CN(12-11) v=0; CH3CN(12-11) v8=1; 13CH3CN(13-12); SiO(5-4); HC3N(24-23) and (26-25); and several transitions of SO, HCOOCH3, CH3OCH3, C2H5CN. All of these lines are known to be disk tracers, apart from SiO, which will be used as a tracer of shocked gas associated with a jet. The continuum will be constructed using the line-free channels in all spectral windows. We stress that it is crucial to have at least one broad bandwidth, with moderate spectral resolution, to identify line-free channels. In fact, the targets are hot molecular cores, whose spectra are well known to be crowded with a large number of lines. The bandwidth of 2 GHz selected in our correlator setup is necessary to identify a sufficient number of line-free channels and thus construct a pure continuum image.

The large data rate required by our correlator setup is due to the spectral resolution of 0.8 km/s requested for the disk tracers (e.g. 13CH3CN) and to the broad 2 GHz bandwidth. As previously discussed (see the correlator setup section), the latter is needed to identify a sufficient number of line-free channels due to the "line forest" present in these hot-core spectra. As for the 0.8 km/s resolution, this is crucial to identify any disk-like feature in the position-velocity plots (e.g. the butterfly-shaped pattern indicating Keplerian rotation).

We wish to resolve circumstellar disks around O-type stars, whose typical distance is several kpc. For the selected targets the largest distance is 7.9 kpc and the expected size of a disk according to theoretical models is on the order of ~4000 AU, which implies an angular size of at least 0.5". In order to resolve this structure, a good compromise between sensitivity and resolution is attained for a beam of about 0.2". From previous observations of the CH3CN(12-11) line towards three of our targets (Beltran et al. 2011, A&A, 525, A151; Beltran et al. 2011, A&A, 532, A91; Cesaroni et al. 2011, A&A, 533, A73), we know that the most extended structures seen in the CH3CN isotopomers are ~2".

The required sensitivity is set by the aim of detecting 13CH3CN in the disks surrounding our targets. The estimated line intensity, based on previous PdBI and SMA observations of three of our targets (Beltran et al. 2011, A&A, 525, A151; Beltran et al. 2011, A&A, 532, A91; Cesaroni et al. 2011, A&A, 533, A73) and the simulations presented in the scientific justification, is 20 mJy/beam. We need to detect this at the 10sigma level to perform the kinematic analysis. This implies a required rms of 2 mJy/beam in the 0.8 km/s channels. This velocity resolution will be sufficent to resolve and properly map the Keplerian velocity pattern (linewidth ~7 km/s). Continuum sensitivity is not an issue for our sources, as the minimum expected continuum flux density is 7 mJy and the continuum noise will be 0.15 mJy/beam, even with the conservative assumption that the line-free bandwidth is only 100 MHz. We require a dynamic range of ~100 in the continuum and ~150 for the brightest lines. We expect that self-calibration may be possible on the continuum source. As explained in the next section, the tracers needed for our scientific goals are expected to show emission over regions <2". Thus the integration time is set by sensitivity considerations and not by (u,v) coverage requirements.
Time constraints: None
User defined calibrations: None

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We resubmit Cycle 2 project 2013.1.00489.S by R. Cesaroni, assigned priority grade B. The observations could be performed in August 2015, but are not guaranteed. Should our Cycle 2 project be completed before the beginning of Cycle 3 observations, we will withdraw the present proposal.
Our aim is to establish whether circumstellar disks exist around O-type (proto)stars, and to characterize them. This is crucial because theory predicts that disk-outflow systems can solve the "radiation-pressure problem" and explain the formation of stars <140 Mo. In a Cycle 0 project, we found 2 Keplerian disks around young B-type stars and proved that disk accretion is the formation route of stars <20 Mo. We now wish to extend our search to the most massive stars. We will observe disk tracers such as 13CH3CN at ~0.2" resolution, sufficient to resolve disks of >0.5", towards 6 selected targets. We will interpret the data with numerical simulations available to us. Note that our project will be successful even if no disk should be detected: in this case we will set a tight upper limit on the disk diameter and prove that disk accretion in O-type stars is not as effective as in lower-mass stars.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00489.S Riccardo Cesaroni "Are there disks around O-type protostars?" The proposal was ranked in the top 10% and assigned priority grade B. The observations are expected to be performed in August 2015, but are not guaranteed due to possible competition with delayed Cycle 1 proposals. For this reason we have decided to re-submit an updated version of the same proposal. However, should our Cycle 2 project be completed before the beginning of Cycle 3 observations, we will be ready to withdraw the present proposal.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
